Supported Pt, Pd, Rh, Ru as Noble and Ni, bimetallic Ni-M (M = Co, Cu, Fe, with Ni/M = 3:1 by weight) as Non-noble catalysts were synthesized, characterized, and tested for CO2 methanation to benchmark and obtain a suitable descriptor. Noble metal catalysts are reduced almost completely with a lower onset of reduction temperature than Non-noble catalysts. The reduced Ni-M catalysts possessed an alloy phase in each as substantiated by a peak shift (∼ 0.2–0.4º) with reference to metallic nickel. The catalysts are benchmarked for their activity at 523 K by reporting turnover frequency ( TOF CO 2 ). The Ni-Fe and Rh catalysts possess maximum TOF CO 2 (∼ 35 × 10−3 sec−1), while Ru, Rh catalysts have better CH4 selectivity (∼99 %) than Ni-Fe (95 %) catalyst. The knowledge of descriptor is revisited for this reaction by calculating surface properties and observed that there exists a volcano relationship between dissociative CO2 adsorption energy (Ediss) and TOF CO 2 . Graphical Abstract Keywords CO2 methanation Transition metal catalysts Dissociative CO2 adsorption energy Volcano plot Descriptor Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The reaction, CO2 hydrogenation to CH4, also known as methanation, finds its technical importance in the utilization of captured CO2 and storage of renewably produced H2 through “power-to-gas (PtG)” concept [1–3]. One of the biggest and most serious global environmental concerns nowadays is the increasing concentration level of CO2 emissions, which keeps on rising day by day. As per a global climate change scientific report recently published by NASA, the concentration of CO2 in the atmosphere reached a level of 422 ppm [4]. The renewable energy integration by intermediary producing hydrogen via water splitting enables CO2 reduction, for example, by producing synthetic natural gas (SNG), CH4, for its utilization in the gas grid and as transport fuel. The CO2 methanation is currently being explored as a feasible process in space exploration, such as the in-situ resource utilization (ISRU) approach [5,6]. Moreover, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) and Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency (JAXA) are now developing life support systems for closed environments in space where this methanation reaction is an important technique for sustainable manned operation in space [7]. Apart from methanation, hydrogenation of CO2 is a potential alternative process to produce methanol (CH3OH), formaldehyde (HCHO), ethanol (C2H5OH) or dimethyl ether (CH3OCH3), and higher hydrocarbons and oxygenates (>C3) to alleviate the dependency on fossil fuels [8,9]. The major reaction involved during the methanation of CO2 is as follows, (1) CO2 + 4H2 → CH4 + 2H2O ΔH = -165 kJ mol−1 and if looked at in a global mechanistic way, it is the combined form of reverse water gas shift (RWGS) reaction which is mildly endothermic in nature, and CO methanation, which is highly exothermic in nature as shown in Eqs. (2) and (3) respectively: (2) CO2 + H2 → CO + H2O ΔH = 41 kJ mol−1 (3) CO + 3H2 → CH4 + H2O ΔH = -206 kJ mol−1 Therefore, this reaction is thermodynamically favoured at low temperature, but as the C꞊O bond is highly stable (∆Gf° = −394.4 kJ mol−1), it requires high temperature and/or the presence of a catalyst that can drive the reaction at sufficiently low to moderate temperature by activating CO2 [10,11]. Catalytic performance for CO2 methanation has been widely studied over Noble and Non-noble transition metals such as Ni, Fe, Co, Cu, Pt, Pd, Rh, Ru, Au etc. with different suitable support or carrier materials like TiO2, ZrO2, CeO2, Al2O3, SiO2 etc.[12–14]. However, it is already proven that Noble metals such as Rh, Ru, Pt, Pd have superior catalytic activity than Non-noble metals. The superior catalytic activity of Noble metals is always attractive but high price and limited availability necessitate the search for an alternative catalyst that could be as promising as those Noble metals. In this case, an effective comparison of the catalytic activity such as rate of CO2 conversion per unit of active site can be very useful. Over the past two decades, Non-noble catalysts, particularly nickel based bimetallic or alloyed catalysts, have gained significant attention for the application in CO2 methanation. However, it is not very clear if these bimetallic or alloy catalysts could surpass the activity of a Noble metal catalysts or in other words, if all the Noble metals are more active than Ni and Ni-based catalysts under the same reaction condition. In particular, how the activity of (i) Ni, (ii) Ni-based bimetallic or alloy and (iii) Noble metals as catalysts scale with the catalytic property was not a subject of investigation and therefore is poorly understood. It has been proposed in previous studies that bimetallic or alloy catalysts might have a synergistic effect that causes an enhancement in catalytic activity or stability [3,11,15]. It indicates that catalysts should have strong adsorption and reduction capacity of CO2, which eventually results into high CO2 conversion. For example, at 523 K and 1 bar, monometallic 17 % Ni/Al2O3 and 17 % Ni-Fe/Al2O3 alloy catalysts exhibited CO2 conversion of 15 % and 21 % with a CH4 selectivity of 98 % and 96 %, respectively [3]. Moreover, by incorporating Co metal to Ni, NiCo bimetallic catalyst was found to enhance the catalytic activity due to increase in surface active sites compared to Ni as well as remarkable resistance to sintering and also operates with high reaction temperature above 523 K [16]. It was corroborated by the fact that, adding a second metal to the ‘parent’ Ni metal decreases the crystallite size of the catalyst as well as well enhances the interaction with CO2. Among the Noble metal catalysts Pt, Pd, Rh, and Ru, only Ru and Rh are known for low temperature (∼523 K) CO2 methanation activity. It was interesting to note that metal loading of Ru, i.e. 3 % or more, favoured the formation of clustered Ru on the surface of the catalyst, which is beneficial to CH4 selectivity, whereas lower loading of Ru (less than 3 %) favours the formation of single Ru atoms which increased CO formation rather than CH4 [17,18]. It is evident from the literature that a lower loading of Noble catalysts (less than or equal to 3 %) are suitable for methane formation, but it is almost impossible for Non-noble catalysts to achieve any appreciable activity. It has been reported in earlier studies that Noble metals have high activity even at lower metal loading due to their high affinity to adsorb the CO2 and activate more molecules or provide more surface-active sites to produce more methane compared to Non-noble catalysts, which do not have sufficiently high affinity for adsorption or availability of more active sites at lower loading [18–20]. Like Ru, Rh catalysts of 1 wt% also favours methane formation (∼100 % selectivity) with CO2 conversion of 40 % at 523 K temperature and 1 atm. pressure [21]. The high activity arises due to dissociatively adsorbed CO2 on each Rh atom, which almost completely inhibited the formation of CO (a byproduct) to give approximately 100 % CH4 selectivity. Other than Rh and Ru, Noble metals like Pt and Pd, even at higher temperatures, favour CO formation due to RWGS reaction, which not only lowered the CH4 selectivity but also had lower activity. For the Pd/Al2O3 catalyst, at higher reaction temperature (573–600 K), it was observed that ∼6 % CO2 conversion is achieved. Even at higher loading of Pd/Al2O3 (5 wt%) than Rh/Al2O3 (2 wt%), Pd showed almost no CO2 conversion, whereas Rh/Al2O3 showed 6.2 % CO2 conversion at 473 K [22,23]. However, under the same reaction condition, these potential Noble and Non-noble transition metal based catalysts were not compared for catalytic CO2 methanation in a single study. It is with this objective these catalysts are considered for benchmarking the activity by evaluating TOF, a signature of a true kinetic parameter. In one of our previous studies, CO2 methanation activity measured in terms of TOF CH 4 was correlated with a pristine surface property, known as the number of d density of states at the Fermi level (NEF). However, to capture the actual trend of catalytic activity of metal catalysts, it is always suggested to choose the adsorbed surface properties rather than the pristine surface properties. So, Density functional theory (DFT) calculations have been deployed to investigate the existence of a suitable correlation between CO2-adsorbed properties and experimental activity, eventually proposing a better descriptor for CO2 methanation. It is important to note that combining Noble and Non-noble metals to reveal the best choice of descriptor for CO2 methanation forms the basis of this study, where the activity trends were benchmarked at the same reaction condition. In this study, γ-Al2O3 supported monometallic Pt, Pd, Rh, Ru, Ni, and bimetallic Ni-M (M = Co, Cu, Fe with Ni/M = 3:1 by weight) catalysts were synthesized, characterized by several phyisco-chemical techniques followed by activity test for CO2 methanation. Particular emphasis was given on the activity comparison between Non-noble (Ni, and three Ni-M catalysts) and Noble metal catalysts and to explain the experimental activity trend by identifying a suitable electronic property of the catalysts. Additionally, each catalyst model surfaces were characterized by the Density functional theory (DFT) method to discern quantitative information of CO2 adsorbed surface in addition to characterization information obtained from other techniques. Considering the significance of the structure-activity relationship, true kinetic information by determining TOF values are correlated with surface properties of the catalysts to propose the best choice of descriptor for this reaction. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst synthesis The monometallic Ni (100Ni), three bimetallic (75Ni25M, M = Co, Cu, and Fe), and four Noble metal (3X, X = Pt, Pd, Rh, Ru) catalysts were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation (IWI) method. The total metal loading was kept at 15 wt% for 100Ni and 75Ni25M whereas it was 3 wt% for Pt, Pd, Rh, and Ru catalysts. Initially, alumina (PURALOX SBa 200, SASOL) was present in Boehmite (γ-AlO(OH)) or Bayerite (Al (OH)3) form, which is a metastable phase of alumina and therefore, it was calcined at 600 ºC for 6 h to obtain gamma phase of the alumina. This γ-Alumina was chosen as a support material for the synthesis of all catalysts. The precursor compounds used in the synthesis are listed in Table 1, along with the nominal composition and nomenclature. A calculated amount of precursor compound was mixed with a known volume of de-ionized water to prepare the corresponding precursor solution. Then, in a dropwise manner, the precursor solution was added to the γ-Al2O3, and simultaneously the mixture was stirred to obtain an almost homogeneous paste. The paste formed was kept in the desiccator first for 6 h and then dried in a muffle furnace at 383 K for 6 h. At this point, the paste mixture was ground into powder, and a temperature cycle was followed between 383 K and 773 K. At last, the calcined catalyst was then reduced at 823 K in a packed bed reactor for 2 h under the flow of H2 gas to achieve the desired monometallic and bi-metallic catalysts. 2.2 Catalyst characterization 2.2.1 Energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) All the synthesized catalysts were characterized to confirm the presence of metals and bulk composition (actual weight percent of metal) by Energy dispersive spectroscopy technique by Oxford Instruments (X-MaxN) with a model number-20, JSM-7610 F. 2.2.2 Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area The specific surface area (m2 g−1), pore size (nm), and pore volume (cc/g) of each catalyst were determined by N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms at 77 K using Autosorb (Quantachrome v3.01) iQ instrument. A 7-point linear plot was used following the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller method over a partial pressure in the range of 0.05–0.3 to determine the BET surface area. Prior to measuring specific surface area, each catalyst was first degassed under vacuum at 573 K for 5 h. 2.2.3 X-ray diffraction (XRD) of calcined and reduced catalysts Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were collected using a PANalytical X’Pert3 powder diffractometer equipped with filtered anode Cu-Kα radiation (wavelength λ = 0.15418 nm) and with a scanning rate of 2.4 ͦ min−1 at 40 kV and 100 mA. The X’pert HighScore Plus and OriginPro 9 software were used to examine the raw data sheet of the catalysts. The average crystallite size of the calcined and reduced alumina supported catalysts was determined using Scherrer’s equation and is given by the following equation: (4) D = k λ β COS θ where, k is a shape factor (0.9), λ is the weighted average X-ray wavelength value of kα radiation source (0.15418 nm), β is half width at full maximum of peak (radians), θ is Bragg’s diffraction angle (peak position in radians) and D is Average crystallite size (nm). 2.2.4 H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) Each calcined catalyst sample was characterized in an AMI-200 (Altamira Instruments) catalyst characterization system. Prior to the experiment, 50 mg of the calcined catalyst was pre-treated in high purity Argon at 473 K for 2 h to remove the adsorbed moisture and impurities. After that, H2-TPR was performed under 10 % H2/Ar (30 ml min−1 at STP) by increasing temperature from 323 K to 1173 K with a ramp rate of 10 K min−1. Finally, the H2-TPR profile for each catalyst was obtained by recording the change in hydrogen consumption during reduction using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The H2 consumption was measured from the H2-TPR profile using calibration amounts of 10 % H2/Ar, which was then used to estimate the percentage reduction (%). 2.2.5 Field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) A supra 40 VP field emission SEM instrument (ZEISS) was used to study the surface morphology of all the reduced samples. This instrument includes a solid state backscattered electron detector, an EDX microanalysis OXFORD "INCA Energie 450 ×3," and a high sensitivity "InLense" secondary electron detector operated at an accelerating voltage of 5 kV, a filament current of 2.345 A, and a working distance of 7 mm. The FESEM images of the samples were taken at various locations throughout the samples. 2.2.6 H2-temperature programmed desorption (H2-TPD) The H2-temperature programmed desorption (H2-TPD) was conducted on an AMI-200 unit (Altamira Instruments) with a thermal conductivity detector. Before performing the H2-TPD analysis, each catalyst was reduced ex-situ with H2 in a down quartz tube flow reactor at 823 K for 2 h. Approximately 200 mg sample was taken in a U-shaped quartz reactor for the characterization and initially reduced in-situ with H2 (30 ml min−1 at STP) 823 K for 0.5 h to ensure sufficient reduction before the TPD test. After H2 reduction, samples were cooled down from 823 K to 323 K in a flow of H2, followed by flushing with Argon (30 ml min−1 at STP) for 30 min to detach the physically adsorbed H2. Desorption was carried out by raising the sample's temperature from 323 K to 773 K at a rate of 10 K min−1, then holding it there for 0.5 h while Argon was flowing. The effluent gas was continuously monitored during the temperature ramping, which led to the recording of an H2-TPD profile. To determine the desorbed moles of H2, the area under the curve from H2-TPD profiles were integrated using calibration pulses of pure H2 of known quantities. Following that, the H2-Uptake values were determined using these desorbed H2 moles. After getting uptake values of all the catalysts, the H2-TPD profile of the γ-Al2O3 support was subtracted from each of the catalysts to account for the effect of hydrogen spillover onto the support. Finally, this H2-Uptake value was considered for the calculation of dispersion (%D) and average particle size (assumed to be hemi-spherical particle). The dispersion (%D) and the particle size estimation for both monometallic and bimetallic catalysts were calculated from H2-TPD based on the following Eqs. (5) and (6) respectively. (5) % D = n . V ads V g . m . w . M . 100 (6) d p = 6 . m . w . D . ρ . δ . N A nm Where, n is the stoichiometry factor (SF = H/M), Vads is the volume adsorbed (cc/g), Vg is the molar volume gas at STP (22414 cc/ mol), m.w. is the molecular weight of the metal, and M is the % metal loading. NA is Avogadro’s number (6.023 ×1023 molecules mol−1), ρ is the metal density (g/cc), δ is the metal surface area (nm2 per metal atom). 2.2.7 Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) of reduced catalysts The finer details of the catalyst microstructure, distribution of the atoms, and particle size across the interfaces of evolved phases were analyzed using TEM (Model number JEM-1400 Flash, JEOL) operated at 80 kV equipped with a field emission source using various magnification indices. These acquired images were analyzed further for particle size estimation. 2.3 Catalytic activity experiment In a typical catalytic activity experiment, a 60 mg catalyst (270 mesh size) was placed in a down-flow tubular reactor (diameter is 10 mm and length 25 cm), and a K-type thermocouple was inserted into the furnace chamber and kept near the catalytic bed (fixed-bed) to control the reaction temperature. Prior to the activity test, the catalyst was reduced at 823 K for 2 h in a continuous flow of pure H2 (30 ml min−1 at STP) and then cooled in H2 flow to the reaction temperature at 523 K. To investigate the catalytic activity of each catalyst at 523 K, the reactant gas mixture (CO2/H2 = 4 %/96 %, 50 ml min−1 at STP) at 1 atm. was introduced into the reactor at a GHSV of 7643 h−1. The flow rate of reactant gas (H2 and CO2) was controlled by separate Mass Flow Controllers (Bronkhorst). The reactor was allowed to reach a steady state for 1 h before starting with the product gas analysis. The reactor outlet gas stream was analyzed by an offline Gas Chromatograph (Nucon 5765), equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID), a methanizer and a carbosieve column, using Argon as a carrier gas (20 ml min−1) to measure the concentration of products (CO, CH4) and unconverted CO2. The activity of the catalysts were reported in terms of rate of CO2 conversion ( r CO 2 ), Yield of products ( Y CH 4 or YCO), CH4 selectivity ( S CH 4 ) and Turnover frequency ( TOF CO 2 ), the formulae of which are expressed by Eqs. (7)-(11) respectively. (7) r CO 2 = X CO 2 100 . F CO 2 W Cat molg − 1 sec − 1 (8) Y CH 4 = F CH 4 , out F CO 2 , out + F CH 4 , out + F CO out . 100 ( % ) (9) Y CO = F CO 2 , out F CO 2 , out + F CH 4 , out + F CO out . 100 ( % ) (10) S CH 4 = Y CH 4 X CO 2 . 100 ( % ) (11) TOF CO 2 = F CO 2 W Cat . X CO 2 100 . 1 M s sec − 1 (12) CB = C out C in (13) C out = F CO 2 , out + F CH 4 , out + F CO out and C in = F CO 2 , in Where, X CO 2 is the CO2 Conversion (%), F CO 2 is the CO2 molar flow rate (mol sec−1), Wcat is the weight of the catalyst taken (g), Fi is the rate of molar flow of component i (mol sec−1) and MS is the surface active sites of the metal (mol gcat −1). From Eq. (11), TOF CO 2 is calculated, which stated as the number of moles of CO2 converted per active site of the catalyst per unit time. In this study, the number of surface-active sites was estimated using the dispersion from H2-TPD, pre-assuming that each surface-active site is associated with one hydrogen atom (i.e. Stoichiometry Factor of 1). Furthermore, to check if deactivation occurred on the catalyst, a parameter called carbon balance (CB) is also calculated by Eq. (12). Also, we have verified that, there is no external diffusion effect occurs for both Noble and Non-noble catalysts. This indicates, it falls under Mears criteria (<0.15) which is given in supplementary section S.1.2. The Mears criterion value is listed in Table S1 of the supplementary information section for all the catalysts. 2.4 Density functional theory calculations 2.4.1 Methods Spin-polarized DFT calculations were performed using the Cambridge Sequential Total Energy Package (CASTEP) [24] module embedded in BIOVIA materials studio. The PBE functional within the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) [25] was used to describe the exchange-correlation interaction. An energy cutoff for the kinetic energy of 360 eV was employed, and the ionic cores were described by ultrasoft pseudopotential [26]. The Brillouin zone integration was approximated by a sum over special k-points (4×4×1) chosen following the Monhorst-Pack scheme [27]. The SCF convergence criteria were set to 1.0×10−6 eV/atom, and for the ions, it was set to 1.0×10−5 eV/atom for energy, 0.05 eV/Å for maximum force, 1.0×10−3 Å for maximum displacement. Mulliken charge analysis was carried out for all the systems to quantify the charge transfer between the surfaces and CO2 moiety. The adsorption energies (Ead) were calculated according to the following equation. (14) E ad = E CO 2 / slab – ( E CO 2 + E slab ) E CO 2 / slab , E CO 2 , and E slab represent the energy of the CO2 moiety adsorbed on the surface, the gas-phase molecule, and the pristine surface, respectively. The more the negative value of Ead indicates that the adsorption is stronger and exothermic. The dissociative CO2 adsorption energy (Ediss) is the energy released (exothermic) or needed (endothermic) when CO2 is dissociated into atomic carbon and oxygen species upon adsorption on the surface. (15) E diss = E CO + O / slab – ( E CO 2 + E slab ) E CO + O / slab is the total energy of CO and O moieties adsorbed on the surface. 2.4.2 Models Five monometallic and three bimetallic alloy catalysts were modelled according to their most stable surfaces. These surfaces are thermodynamically most stable and were confirmed by the presence of their most intense facets in XRD patterns. Monometallic surface models were Ni(111), Pt(111), Pd(111), Rh(111), and Ru(0001), while bimetallic surface models were Ni3Fe(111), Ni3Co(111) and Ni3Cu(111) having Ni3M as a bulk unit cell (space group of Pm-3 m, 221). All the surfaces were cleaved from their respective optimized bulk unit cell. The surface model consists of a p(2×2) supercell with a total of four-layer, where the bottom two-layer were kept fixed to bulk equilibrium position, and the top two-layer relaxed during pristine and adsorbed surface optimization. A vacuum slab of thickness 12 Å was added to break the periodicity in the z-direction. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Metal loading and surface area of the calcined catalysts The actual (bulk) metal loading in each of the synthesized catalysts was determined by EDS so that they can be compared with the nominal (experimental) values, as shown in Table 2. It is seen from Table 2 that percentages of the corresponding metals actually present are similar to their nominal values. The surface area of the supported catalysts, which are also given in Table 2, is lower than that of the γ-Al2O3 support, which has a BET surface area of 208 m2 g−1. The lowering of the surface area of the supported catalyst is due to the partial blocking of pores of the support by the deposited active components [12]. Furthermore, there was no specific trend in the measured surface area for the Noble and Non-noble metal based catalysts series. 3.2 Structural characterization of calcined catalysts In Fig. 1(A), the XRD patterns of the γ-Al2O3 supported Non-noble catalysts calcined at 773 K are shown in the 2θ range of 30° - 80°, and they confirm the presence of major metal oxide species, such as NiO, CuO, Co3O4 and Fe2O3 in 100Ni, 75Ni25Cu, 75Ni25Co, 75Ni25Fe catalysts respectively. For 100Ni, the five NiO reflections were observed at 2θ of 37.46° (111), 43.48° (200), 63.10° (220), 75.65° (311), and 79.55° (222) which are consistent with previous studies [12,13,15,16]. For the 75Ni25M catalysts, characteristic phases located at 2θ of 31.25° (220), 36.84° (311), 55.51º (422) and 59.21º (511) are representative of Co3O4 species; at 2θ of 61.77° (113) is of CuO species; and at 2θ of 50.15º (024) and 62.80º (440) are indicative of Fe2O3 (Hematite) oxide species [12,16,28]. At a lower diffraction angle, the intensity of the characteristic NiO peaks was reduced, however, for a higher (>70°) angle, the NiO peak was non-existent in the three 75Ni25M catalysts. The intensities of the second metal oxide species were much less compared to that of NiO, as lesser wt% of the second metal is present in the respective calcined catalysts, which would give rise to smaller size crystals. The XRD patterns of the γ-Al2O3 supported Noble metal catalysts were recorded and are shown in the 2θ range of 30º to 80º in Fig. 1(B). All the catalysts, namely 100Pt, 100 Pd, 100Rh, and 100Ru characterized with the respective metal oxides PtO, PdO, Rh2O3, and RuO2 are having very low intensity. This can be due to the lower metal loading of 3 wt% as well as XRD detection limitation, it is difficult to be detected through XRD analysis. Nonetheless, for 100Pt, 100 Pd, 100Rh and 100Ru calcined catalysts, 2θ position at 62.73º (311) indicates the presence of PtO peak, 33.73º (100) and 54.63º (110) represents the characteristic peaks of tetragonal PdO, whereas, 2θ at 32.62º (104) assigned as Rh2O3 peaks and 2θ at 35.16º (101) and 54.46º (211) identified as tetragonal RuO2 peaks respectively [29–33]. Finally, the peaks at 2θ 37.14º, 39.7º, 46º and 66.98º correspond to (311), (222), (400), and (440) facets of γ-Al2O3 are clearly observed in Fig. 1(A) and Fig. 1(B) for all the supported catalysts [3,13,30,33]. 3.3 Redox properties of calcined catalysts: H2-TPR The H2-TPR characterization tests were conducted to determine the reducibility of the γ-Al2O3 supported Non-noble and Noble metal catalysts, and the corresponding profiles for each catalyst are shown in Fig. 2A and Fig. 2(B). This reducibility indicates the ease of reduction by observing the onset of reduction of the calcined catalyst and to infer the strength of interaction of a metal with the support. It also confirmed the types of oxide phases present in the bulk of the catalyst. The reduction profiles of 100Ni, 75Ni25Co, 75Ni25Cu, and 75Ni25Fe catalysts are compared in Fig. 2(A). The main reduction peak of 100Ni appeared at ∼ 830 K, whereas the peak attributed to bulk NiO reduction to Ni0 was suggested earlier [12]. Two peaks were also evident at around 610 K and 970 K, representing weak and strong interaction between the NiO species and the support, respectively [12]. The H2-TPR profile of the calcined 75Ni25M catalysts was characteristically different compared to pure 100Ni catalyst because of: (i) reduction at low temperature and (ii) the occurrence of multiple peaks. For example, 75Ni25Co possessed three peaks at 610 K, 690 K, and 830 K and interestingly, the reduction of this sample started at an earlier temperature compared to the 100Ni catalyst. The first two peaks occurred in close succession denoting the reduction of metallic oxide of Co3O4 to Co metal with the highly dispersed and reduced NiO, reconfirming the presence of Co3O4 and NiO via XRD of calcined 75Ni25Co catalyst [12,34]. The final peak position and shape are very similar to that of 100Ni and suggest bulk NiO reduction as remained in the catalyst. The TPR profile of the 75Ni25Cu catalyst was obtained with three distinct intensive peaks. The initial peak encountered at 510 K appeared due to the reduction of Cu2+ to Cu0 of the CuO-NiO solid metal oxide solution [12,28]. The broad intermediate peak, centered at around 605 K, was correlated with the reduction of Ni2+ to Ni0 as referred by previous studies, which shows the presence of copper improves the reduction of the parent metal (Ni) oxide [12,28]. The final broad peak centered at ∼ 750 K might be the NiO reduced species interacting with the γ-Al2O3 support [12,28]. The reduction of 75Ni25Fe is associated with two peaks: (i) one low intensity peak at 523 K representing the simultaneous reduction of NiO to Ni metal and Fe2O3 (hematite) to Fe3O4 (magnetite), and (ii) a very broad peak in a range of 610–900 K, indicating the reduction of Fe3O4 (magnetite) to FeO and then FeO to metallic Fe simultaneously with NiO reduction to metallic Ni. In comparison to 75Ni25Co and 75Ni25Cu, this broad peak contains the reduction of bulk oxide species of Iron and Nickel simultaneously, which indicates bulk Ni-Fe alloy formation [3,12,15]. The reduction peaks of 75Ni25Fe catalyst compared to 75Ni25Cu shifted towards high temperature which indicates high reduction temperature associated with Iron oxides compared to Cobalt or Copper oxides [35]. From the H2-TPR profile of the Non-noble catalysts, the effect of reduction by adding a second metal (Co, Cu, Fe) to the parent Ni catalyst is substantiated by shifting of reduction peaks to a lower temperature and simultaneous reduction of two different oxides, which may increase the chance of alloy formation in the reduced catalyst. The H2-TPR profiles of four Noble metal catalysts are shown in Fig. 2(B). The reduction profile for 100Pt contains four peaks at around 353 K, 501 K, 670 K, and 805 K. The first (353 K) and second (501 K) peak is associated with the reduction of Pt4+ (bulk PtOX) species, barely interacting with the γ-Al2O3 support. The third and fourth reduced peak occurring at 670 K and 805 K, respectively, shows a strong interaction between metal oxide (PtO) and γ-alumina support, respectively. The third and fourth reduced peaks of PtOX confirmed the reduction of Pt2+ to Pt0 [36,37]. The H2-TPR characterization of 100 Pd shows two reduction peaks; the first peak occurring at ∼ 360 K is associated with β-PdH reduction, whereas the high temperature peak occurring at ∼ 550 K is due to bulk PdO reduction to form Pd metal [37]. The 100Rh catalyst showed only one reduction peak occurring at ∼ 370 K which indicates the reduction of rhodium oxide (Rh2O3) to metallic Rh. This low temperature peak is associated with the well dispersed Rh2O3 species [38]. Finally, the H2-TPR profile of the 100Ru catalyst possessed two reduction peaks. The first one is located at ∼ 350 K, which shows the reduction of RuO3 species. The second peak is broad, ranging from 450 to 500 K, and is due to the reduction of RuO2 to metallic Ru [19]. The percentage reduction (%) of each catalyst was calculated and also tabulated in Table 2. The percentage reduction refers to the extent of metal oxide reduction to corresponding metal and is indicative of the availability of the metal sites. The calcined 100Ni (63 %) and 75Ni25Co (67 %) samples were similar, whereas the Ni-Fe bimetallic catalyst has a better percentage of reduction (76 %). In contrast, the percentage reduction of the bimetallic Ni-Cu catalyst was 57 %, which was lower than the Ni catalyst. Therefore, it may be argued that not all Ni-based bimetallic catalysts have better reduction characteristics than pure Ni. The calcined Noble metal catalyst was found to have near complete reduction upon calculation of percentage reduction and is reported to be consistent with previous studies [3,15,28]. The steps involved in the calculation of the percentage reduction of metal oxides (%) are reported in supplementary section S.1.1. 3.4 Structural characterization of reduced catalysts The XRD patterns of reduced γ-Al2O3 supported Non-noble and Noble catalysts were obtained and shown in Fig. 3A and Fig. 3(B), respectively. The XRD patterns of all the catalysts are shown in the range of 30° to 80° to identify the possible phases and the facets formed after reducing the catalysts at 823 K. In Fig. 3(A), the presence of metallic Ni phase was observed with peaks at 44.6°, 51.9°, and 76.4°, due to the (111), (200), and (220) facets of the face centered cubic (FCC) bulk structure [3,12,15,28]. On the other hand, reduced 75Ni25Co bimetallic possessed characteristic peaks at 2θ position of 44.5º (111) and 51.7º (200), indicative of slightly shifted Ni rich Ni-Co facets. Such Ni-Co facets could be due to a Ni1-xCox alloy phase formed upon reduction, which is consistent with previous reports [39]. Similarly, characteristic peaks occurring at 44.2º (111) and 51.5º (200) for 75Ni25Cu, and at 44.1º (111) and 51.6º (200) for 75Ni25Fe catalysts, are visibly shifted compared to the metallic Ni peaks in the 100Ni catalyst. This shifting to a lower 2θ position in the Ni rich Ni-Cu and Ni-Fe catalysts, 75Ni25Cu and 75Ni25Fe, were also observed in previous studies, which suggests a different crystalline phase formed in those catalysts, indicative of alloy formation [15,39]. The alloy phase formed in 75Ni25Cu could be of Ni1-xCux type, whereas in 75Ni25Fe catalyst could be of Ni3Fe type. The alloy phases formed in three bimetallic catalysts are also characteristically different. For example, Ni1-xMx (M=Co, Cu) are disordered in nature, whereas Ni3Fe is an ordered alloy [39,40]. The absence of metallic phases of Co, Cu, and Fe as well as bimetal oxides suggests that adequate reduction was achieved at the specified temperature. The XRD patterns of Ni and three Ni-M catalysts also evidenced the characteristic γ-Al2O3 peaks occurring at 37.2º (311), 39.6º (222), 45.6º (400), and 66.9º (440), which is consistent with a previous study [33]. The Fig. 3(B) represents the XRD patterns of the reduced Noble metal catalysts. A very small peak located at 2θ of 39.6º is indicative of metallic Pt, and the small intensity of the XRD peak is indicative of high dispersion of the metallic Pt in the 100Pt catalyst [41]. Like 100Pt catalyst, 100 Pd and 100Ru catalysts were identified with the corresponding metallic peaks located at 2θ position of 40.18º (111) for Pd (face centered cubic) whereas, 39.5º (111) and 44.1º (101) for Ru (hexagonal closed packed) respectively [19,37]. In the case of the 100Rh catalyst, peaks of γ-Al2O3 phases were identified only and the absence of Rh metallic peak suggests that metallic Rh exists as highly dispersed nanoparticles. The crystallite sizes of the reduced Non-noble catalysts were calculated using the Scherrer equation for the very intense peak observed in the corresponding XRD pattern [38]. The crystallite sizes are reported in Table 3, which indicates that the alloy peak in 75Ni25M catalysts are broadened compared to pure Ni. The crystallite sizes of the Noble metals were not calculated and are considered to be highly dispersed nanoparticles compared to the Non-noble catalysts. 3.5 Particle size and surface morphology: FESEM of reduced catalysts The FESEM images of γ-Al2O3 supported reduced Non-noble (100Ni, 75Ni25Co, 75Ni25Co, 75Ni25Fe) and Noble metal (100Pt, 100 Pd, 100Rh, 100Ru) catalysts were captured and shown in Fig. 4. The morphology and average particle size of the reduced catalysts were obtained for all the catalysts. Moreover, the presence of metals in the catalyst was confirmed by the EDS elemental analysis with colour mapping, which is shown in Fig. 4. The average particle size of all the reduced catalysts is listed in Table 3. For 100Ni (Fig. 4(a)), the images revealed that the particles were smooth with a near uniform distribution. Substituting 25 wt% Ni with Co, Cu, or Fe in the 75Ni25M catalysts, resulted in the particles having an irregular shape and agglomeration behavior, signifying a change in morphology. Interestingly, for the reduced 75Ni25Co catalyst, the agglomeration of particles is visible in Fig. 4(b), whereas for the 75Ni25Cu catalyst, the roughness of the particles is observed. Among all the Non-noble catalysts, 75Ni25Fe catalyst exhibited smaller particles. The FESEM images of all the Noble metal catalysts supported on γ-Al2O3 are shown in Fig. 4. From the representative images, it is clearly observed that Noble metal particles except Pd, are uniformly distributed, indicating a good dispersion of the metal particles as compared to Non-noble catalysts. The Palladium nanoparticles are relatively larger compared to Pt, Rh, and Ru. The same catalyst also possessed a relatively larger intensity XRD peak. 3.6 Surface site and dispersion characterization: H2-TPD of reduced catalysts The reduced γ-Al2O3-supported Non-noble and Noble catalysts were characterized by H2-TPD and the corresponding profiles are presented in Figures S1A and S1B of the supplementary information section. The TPD profiles indicated the desorption behaviour of the catalysts based on hydrogen gas adsorbed over the supported metal or metal alloy sites present on the surface of the catalysts. From the Non-noble metal pool, the H2-TPD profiles displayed a single desorption peak, centered at around 400 K, with small variations among the 100Ni, 75Ni25Co, 75Ni25Cu, and 75Ni25Fe catalysts. The obtained desorption peak corresponds to the release of chemisorbed hydrogen from the surface site of each catalyst. The corresponding net H2-desorbed values are used to calculate the active surface area of the catalysts and are reported in Table 3. While determining the net H2-desorbed amount, the H2-TPD profile of γ-Al2O3 was taken into account. A stoichiometry ratio of Metal or Metal alloy/Hsurface = 1 was considered, which has also been justified in previous studies [19,42]. The net H2-desorbed values of 100Ni, 75Ni25Co 75Ni25Cu, and 75Ni25Fe catalysts were 80, 58, 54, and 95 µmol g−1 respectively, showing non-monotonicity with respect to 100Ni. Furthermore, Figure S1A shows that the desorption peak for 75Ni25Fe catalyst is shifted towards a higher temperature compared to pure Ni, suggesting that hydrogen species were more strongly to the alloy. From the Noble pool, the H2-TPD profiles as shown in Figure S1B, also displayed a single desorption peak below 400 K for each catalyst. The H2-desorbed values of 100Pt, 100 Pd, 100Rh, and 100Ru are 76, 81, 135, and 118 µmolg−1 respectively, and as before used to calculate the dispersions. It was observed that among all the Noble metal catalysts, Rhodium has the highest surface metal sites, and it was also larger compared to the highest surface sites containing Non-noble catalyst i.e. 75Ni25Fe (95 µmol g−1), which is listed in Table 3. From Eq. 6, the particle size was determined from H2-TPD analysis for all the reduced catalysts and are reported in Table 3. The metallic particle size from H2-TPD and TEM was compared and found not in direct agreement. However, similarity in the particle size trend was established from XRD, TEM, and FESEM for Non-noble catalysts and from FESEM and TEM for Noble metal catalysts. It is also evident that, among all the catalysts, 100Pt (49.74 %, 49.74 m2 g−1) and 100Rh (46.25 %, 46.25 m2 g−1) were characterized to be the highly dispersed and high active metal surface area, which appears due to low metal loading of Noble catalysts (3 %) as compared to Non-noble catalysts (15 %). 3.7 Particle size and structure characterization: TEM of reduced catalysts The TEM images of γ-Al2O3 supported reduced Non-noble and Noble metal catalysts were captured and their respective histogram of the particle size distribution for each image is present in Fig. 5. Moreover, the metal particle and the support can be identified by their colour contrast difference. The metal particles (darker in colour contrast) are encircled with red colour in Figs. 5(a), 5(e), 5(f), 5(g), and 5(h), whereas the support (lighter in colour contrast) particles are marked with a blue arrow. The average particle size of the reduced catalysts is listed in Table 3. From the Non-noble series of catalysts, the particle sizes of 100Ni (18.5 ± 3.35 nm) are larger than those observed for the alloyed bimetallic catalysts (75Ni25Co = 12.6 ± 2.35 nm, 75Ni25Cu = 14.8 ± 2.14 nm and 75Ni25Fe = 10.3 ± 2.25 nm). This highlights the importance of the second metal in decreasing particle size which is confirmed by XRD, FESEM, and TEM analysis. Similarly, for Noble catalysts, average particle size was calculated and compared with respect to FESEM analysis. It was observed that, only 100Rh and 100Ru catalysts maintained the similar trend as FE-SEM analysis. Among all the Noble and Non-noble catalysts, 100Rh possessed the smallest average particle size (4.4 nm) catalysts. 3.8 Catalytic activity measurement The catalytic performances of all eight catalysts towards CO2 methanation were evaluated based on CH4 yield, rate of CO2 conversion, selectivity of CH4, and turnover frequency of CO2 conversion. Initially, with only γ-Al2O3 support, the reaction was conducted at 523 K and 1 atm. pressure, and no activity was reported. Afterwards all the supported catalysts were tested and found to be active for CO2 methanation but to a significantly varying extent. When the product yield was calculated from the amount of CO and CH4 formed and plotted in Fig. 6, it was revealed that 100Rh, 100Ru, and 75Ni25Fe catalysts possessed a much higher yield of methane ( Y CH 4 ) than the rest of the catalysts. Also, for these three catalysts, the yield of CO (YCO) was much less compared to Y CH 4 and thus can be termed as methane selective catalysts. A comparable activity ( Y CH 4 and Y CO ) was found for 100Ni and 75Ni25Co catalysts which can be ranked below the above mentioned three catalysts. The remaining catalysts which are 75Ni25Cu, 100 Pd, and 100Pt, exhibited the lowest activity among all the catalysts with almost equal yields of CH4 and CO. The average values of r CO 2 along with their standard deviation for both Noble and Non-noble metal catalysts are shown in Table 4. Surprisingly, as a supported Non-noble catalysts, the average converted rate of CO2 was the highest for 75Ni25Fe catalyst (2.88 × 10−6 gmol gcat −1 sec−1), also possessed the highest methane selectivity ( S CH 4 = 95 %), and the least was for 75Ni25Cu catalyst (0.57× 10−6 gmol gcat−1 sec−1) with the least selectivity ( S CH 4 = 41 %). The other two catalysts, namely 100Ni and 75Ni25Co had intermediate rates (0.87× 10−6 gmol gcat −1 sec−1) but relatively high methane selectivity ( S CH 4 = 87 %). The poor selectivity towards methane for 75Ni25Cu may arise due to this catalyst favouring the RWGS reaction (formation of CO) [16]. The Ni-Co alloy activity does not differ with Ni metal sites, whereas highly active Ni3Fe sites caused a larger catalytic rate towards methane. Similar inferences about different Ni-based alloy catalysts were drawn previously [12]. On the other hand, among the four Noble metals, 100Rh catalyst possessed the highest rate of CO2 conversion with 98 % selectivity to methane, which is almost 4.3 times higher than nickel metal and 1.3 times higher than the most active Non-noble catalyst (75Ni25Fe). Interestingly, at the present operating condition 100Rh catalyst performed better than 100Ru which has r CO 2 of 0.87× 10−6 gmol gcat −1 sec−1 with 99 % methane selectivity. Therefore, both 100Rh and 100Ru are highly methane selective catalyst but the former has higher catalytic rate than the later. The 100Pt and 100 Pd were inferior in terms of catalytic rates and similar to the 75Ni25Cu catalyst, the methane selectivity for the 100 Pd catalyst was better. These two catalysts were even less active than 100Ni and 75Ni25Co, which ranks them at a much lower position than other Noble and Non-noble catalysts. It appears that Pt and Pd metal sites are not effective for methane formation and favours the RWGS reaction to produce CO in significant amounts, like it was observed in the Ni-Cu alloy catalyst [43]. Therefore, based on the rate of CO2 conversion and selectivity towards methane the following trends exist for the studied Noble and Non-noble catalysts. Rate of CO2 conversion ( r CO 2 ): 100Rh > 75Ni25Fe > 100Ru > 100Ni ∼ 75Ni25Co > 100 Pd ∼ 100Pt ∼ 75Ni25Cu Methane selectivity ( S CH 4 ) : 100Ru ∼ 100Rh > 75Ni25Fe > 100Ni ∼ 75Ni25Co > 100 Pd > 100Pt > 75Ni25Cu The above rate-based trend indicates that Non-noble metal catalyst (75Ni25Fe) can show better activity than certain Noble metals (100Ru, 100 Pd, 100Pt). It also suggests that not all the Ni-based bimetallic alloys are as active as 75Ni25Fe and only 100Rh, 100Ru, and the Ni-Fe alloy with a Ni:Fe wt. ratio 3:1 has superior activity than 100Ni. Like the rate-based trend, the trend in methane selectivity was more or less similar and the only difference that emerged is that the 100Ru catalyst had similar methane selectivity to 100Rh and they had the highest values among all the Noble and Non-noble catalysts. This high selectivity can be potentially linked to the high dispersion of Rh and Ru metal particles and their ability to promote the dissociation of CO2 into reactive intermediates. The findings from the activity and selectivity are highly interesting because despite higher dispersion and smaller particle size of Noble metals (Ru, Rh, Pd, Pt) compared to Ni and Ni based alloys, only 100Rh and 100Ru are found to be competing with Ni based Ni-Fe alloy catalyst. This comparison observed are only suggestive and provide an immediate basis to benchmark the catalyst performance. The turnover frequencies (TOF) for the CO2 conversion rate and CH4 formation rate of all eight catalysts at 523 K were calculated to practically benchmark the performance of each catalyst. The reactivity data i.e. turnover frequency ( TOF CO 2 and TOF CH 4 ) values are reported in Table 4. According to the definition of TOF, an intrinsic activity parameter, it is defined as the number of CO2 molecule conversion (or CH4 molecule formation) per second per metal or metal alloy active site [12]. It can be seen from Table 4. that, except 75Ni25Fe, all other Non-noble catalysts had similar TOF CO 2 but different TOF CH 4 . The TOF CO 2 of 75Ni25Cu is found to be similar to 100Ni catalyst, which is due to the former catalyst having a lower number of surface sites than later. As the Ni-Cu alloy catalyst formed more CO than CH4, so the TOF CH 4 was the lowest for it among the Non-noble catalysts. The turnover frequency ( TOF CO 2 and TOF CH 4 ) of 75Ni25Co are relatively better than 100Ni because this catalyst retained almost similar rates of CO2 conversion and CH4 formation. The difference between the TOF CO 2 and TOF CH 4 can be ascribed to the formation of CO since the carbon balance on all the catalysts was > 97 %, clearly showed that all the catalysts under the reaction condition did not suffer from carbon deposition. The absence of carbon deposition is also consistent with time-on-stream studies, which show no deactivation occurring. The average TOF CO 2 and TOF CH 4 for 75Ni25Fe catalyst were 36.6 × 10−3 s−1 and 34.7 × 10−3 s−1, respectively, while that for 100Rh catalyst was 33.6 × 10−3 s−1 and 32.9 × 10−3 s−1 respectively. So, the TOF of 100Rh and 75Ni25Fe are similar and both the catalysts can be benchmarked as superior CO2 methanation catalysts, although the rate of CO2 consumption for 100Rh was 1.3 times higher than for the 75Ni25Fe catalyst. So, with relatively smaller alloy sites present in the Ni-Fe bimetallic catalyst, it was able to activate CO2 to a similar extent as that of 100Rh. It is quite interesting to see that one Non-noble catalyst is possessing almost equal intrinsic activity to that of a Noble metal catalyst. However, 100Ru which is a well-known methanation catalyst, performed less than 100Rh and 75Ni25Fe but was better than 100Ni. The TOF CO 2 and TOF CH 4 was almost the same because this catalyst possessed the highest methane selectivity among all the catalysts studied. The underperformance might be due to the formation of oxide overlayer on the Ru0 particles after reduction of RuO2 species [44]. In previous studies also, for 3 % Ru/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, at 523 K and at 1 atm., the X CO 2 is around 8 %. Furthermore, the reaction performed using five different loading of Ru/γ-Al2O3 (1–5 %) reported negligible formation of CO [19]. Among the remaining two Noble metals the TOF CH 4 of 100 Pd catalyst was slightly better than the least active 100Pt catalyst. Similar to the analysis of the rates and selectivity given above, the following trends in TOF CO 2 and TOF CH 4 can be drawn for γ-Al2O3 supported 100Rh, 100Ru, 100Pt, 100 Pd, 100Ni, 75Ni25Fe, 75Ni25Co, and 75Ni25Cu catalysts for CO2 methanation conducted at 523 K and 1 atm. with a CO2:H2 inlet molar ratio of 1:24. The trend in TOF CO 2 : 75Ni25Fe > 100Rh > 100Ru ∼ 75Ni25Co > 100Ni ∼ 75Ni25Cu > 100Pt ∼ 100 Pd The trend in TOF CH 4 : 75Ni25Fe > 100Rh > 100Ru > 75Ni25Co > 100Ni > 100 Pd > 75Ni25Cu > 100Pt Therefore, the present study revealed that the relative performance among Noble and Non-noble catalysts in terms of the rate of CO2 conversion, TOF CO 2 , and TOF CH 4 during CO2 methanation strongly depend on the number of available surface sites and properties of surface sites. It is noteworthy to mention that the Non-noble Ni based Ni-Fe alloy catalyst can produce almost similar activity to that of a Noble metal, Rh. Such a similarity in activity occurs despite the Noble metal catalysts possessing smaller particle sizes compared to the Non-noble catalysts, as shown using FESEM and TEM. The higher loading involved for the Non-noble catalysts may be the cause for larger particle sizes for these catalysts. However, particle size could not account for the observed trend in turnover frequency ( TOF CO 2 , and TOF CH 4 ). Thus, it is meaningful to characterize the surfaces in each catalyst using a technique that can reveal the fundamental difference in the catalyst’s electronic properties. This could be related to the surface properties of the sites or the surface phenomena such as CO2 adsorption which is the first step in CO2 activation. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations are suitable for the characterization of the surface electronic properties of the metal and metal alloy catalysts [45–49]. The activation of CO2 could lead to react with more facile activated H2 by forming adsorbed H to form intermediates, which are necessary for CH4 formation. So, it is important to understand the CO2 adsorption characteristics on the surface sites of metal and metal alloy catalyst, the potential reason for the activity trend might then be elucidated. 3.9 Electronic characterization based on surface properties: DFT calculations 3.9.1 Molecular adsorption of CO2 On the monometallic Ni(111), Pt(111), Pd(111), Ru(0001), and Rh(111) surfaces, the CO2 molecule was adsorbed on the bridge site between two surface atoms, as shown in Figure S2 of the supplementary information section. In the case of a bimetallic alloy catalyst modelled as a bulk Ni3M (M = Fe, Co, Cu) unit, similar close-packed (111) surfaces were considered. Since there are two different (Ni and M) metals are on the surface, CO2 was adsorbed on the bridge site between one Ni atom and the M metal atom for the respective Ni3Fe, Ni3Co, and Ni3Cu structures, as given in Figure S2. All the surfaces with CO2 at the bridge site were optimized to obtain the minimum energy configuration. The optimized structures for both the monometallic and bimetallic surfaces are shown in Figure S2. The changes that occurred on each surface upon CO2 adsorption are quantified by the change in: (i) ∠OCO, (ii) ∑CO bond elongation, and (iii) charge transferred from the catalyst surface to CO2 ( q CO 2 ) and reported in Table 5. The molecular adsorption energy of CO2 (Ead) measures the thermodynamic feasibility of CO2 adsorption, where positive and negative adsorption energies are measures of CO2 endothermic and exothermic adsorption, respectively, as given in Table 5. The charge calculation values reported are based on Mulliken charge analysis [45], and it was observed that all the surfaces except Pt(111) and Pd(111) have relatively high q CO 2 , which suggests strong chemisorption occurred. The CO2 adsorption results in strong endothermic chemisorption on Ni, Ni3Fe, Ni3Co, and Ni3Cu surfaces with a respective Ead of 0.42, 0.17, 0.26, and 0.46 eV. In contrast to these Non-noble mono and bimetals, the Noble metals such as Rh(111) and Ru(0001) showed exothermic CO2 adsorption with Ead around −0.07 eV and −0.20 eV, respectively. Exothermic CO2 adsorption is usually preferred in accordance with thermodynamics, where no additional energy is required. Irrespective of endothermic or exothermic adsorption, the charge gained by CO2 molecule on interacting with chemisorption-induced surfaces varies from −0.41 to −0.49, which indicates that charge transfer plays a significant role in the activation of CO2, which may or may not result into exothermic chemisorption. In comparison with the gas phase CO2 (CO bond length, 1.171 Å, ∠OCO = 180°) structural changes of adsorbed CO2, including the CO bond elongation and bending of ∠OCO, were significant in all the surfaces, except Pt and Pd, as shown in Table 5. Simultaneous elongation and bending of the CO bond and ∠OCO of adsorbed CO2 molecule along with the reasonable charge transferred to the anti-bonding orbital of CO2 on Ni, Ni3M (M=Fe, Co, Cu), Ru, Rh surfaces indicate the presence of anionic CO2 δ−species. The occurrence of this particular activated state of CO2 is regarded as an intrinsic precursor for the CO2 dissociation and, hence, subsequent intermediate formation reactions. No significant interaction between the Pt(111) and Pd(111) surface with CO2 occurred in terms of Mulliken charge transfer ( q CO 2 = −0.03, −0.11 for Pt and Pd) from the aforementioned surfaces to the CO2 molecule. It is, therefore, noted that CO2 is physisorbed on Pt(111) and Pd(111), where these surfaces cannot activate CO2 to a significant extent. Among the Ni, Ni3Fe, Ni3Co, Ni3Cu, Rh, and Ru surfaces on which CO2 chemisorption is induced, a large amount of electrons has been transferred to the CO2 molecule, thus facilitating CO2 activation. 3.9.2 Dissociative adsorption of CO2 Though molecularly adsorbed CO2 on each catalyst surface suggested different degrees of activation, a more intuitive approach for understanding the extent of activation is revealed by studying dissociative adsorption. The adsorbed species on each surface are molecularly adsorbed CO and atomically adsorbed oxygen. On the monometallic surfaces, CO was adsorbed on the top site of one of the surface atoms, whereas O was adsorbed on the 3-fold FCC hollow site, as shown in Figure S3 of the supplementary information section. Since there are two types of atoms in the case of bimetallic alloy surface, CO was adsorbed on the top site of Ni metal while O was adsorbed at the 3-fold FCC hollow site constructed by two Ni and one M (M = Fe, Co, and Cu) atom as shown in Figure S3. Upon studying the dissociative adsorption of CO2, the Ediss values are reported in Table 5. The calculated Ediss may vary up to ±0.15 eV according to the adsorption site chosen for CO, O. A strong exothermic dissociative adsorption of CO2 was identified on Ru(0001), Ni3Fe(111), Rh(111), and Ni3Co(111) surface with a respective Ediss of −1.26, −0.62, −0.54 and −0.40 eV. The CO2-physisorption-induced surfaces such as Pt(111) and Pd(111) and chemisorption-induced surfaces such as Ni(111) and Ni3Cu(111) resulted in endothermic dissociative adsorption of CO2 with Ediss of 0.65, 0.63, 0.24, 0.44 eV respectively. Based on Ediss, the decreasing order of dissociative CO2 adsorption is as follows: Ru > Ni3Fe > Rh > Ni3Co > Ni > Ni3Cu > Pd > Pt By comparing the molecular and dissociative adsorption energy of CO2, it is clear that CO2 prefers to adsorb dissociatively on surfaces which induces chemisorption of CO2. According to Bligaard et al., dissociative chemisorption energy was proposed as an acceptable descriptor of the catalytic activity for a series of catalytic reactions, such as CO, N2, O2, and NO hydrogenation . This property measures the reactivity for surface-catalyzed reactions with a single rate-determining step [50]. Since chemisorbed CO2 δ- species is an intrinsic precursor for CO2 dissociation into CO and O species, it is often considered the rate-determining step and the most vital step to form different products through selective intermediates. 3.10 Correlation between intrinsic activity (TOF) and surface adsorption property Understanding descriptors brings about rationality towards trends in experimentally measured catalytic activity, thereby reducing the catalyst design complexity. Rather than being an empirical principle, the Sabatier principle had no vital role in catalyst screening and its design until the introduction of DFT [51], where the DFT-calculated adsorbed surface energetics (adsorption energy, dissociative adsorption energy, and enthalpy of reaction) may result into a volcano plot characterizing activity and adsorbed surface property. Sabatier's principle explains the volcano in such a way that very weak or very strong binding between an adsorbate and a catalyst surface results in the poor activity of the catalyst [52,53]. The Sabatier principle and volcano curve are inevitable in the rational design of catalysts, which aid in predicting the catalytic activity qualitatively. In one of our previous studies, a surface electronic property called the number of d-density of states at the Fermi level (NEF) was found to be linearly correlated with the CO2 hydrogenation activity for a series of γ-Al2O3 supported monometallic Ni, and Cu and Fe based Ni alloyed catalysts. Being a better electronic descriptor than the d-band center (εd), NEF gives some insights into why specific Ni-based alloy catalysts are active through the linear correlation with the experimentally calculated turnover frequency of CH4 ( TOF CH 4 ) for CO2 methanation [12]. Since NEF is only a pristine surface property that does not account for the reactants interacting with the catalytic system and is limited for Ni and Ni-based bimetallic alloy catalysts, attempts were made to find a suitable descriptor based on the interaction between key reactant molecules, i.e., CO2 and the surface sites of Ni, Ni-based Non-noble alloys and pure, Noble metals. DFT-calculated adsorbed surface energetics, such as molecular CO2 adsorption energy (Ead) and CO2 dissociative adsorption energies (Ediss), were tried to correlate with the TOF CO 2 an intrinsic rate as shown in Fig. 7A and Fig. 7(B) respectively. A scattered plot with no significant correlation is observed when TOF CO 2 is plotted with Ead, as shown in Fig. 7(A). In contrast to this, a clear volcano relation exists when Ediss is chosen as the adsorbed surface property, as shown in Fig. 7(B). This particular correlation arising with the Ediss might be because when CO2 is molecularly adsorbed on the surfaces which induce its chemisorption, CO2 prefers to undergo its dissociation and to adsorb dissociatively (CO and O) than retaining its associative adsorption nature. This highly activated, chemisorbed CO2 δ- species acts as an intrinsic precursor for the exothermic dissociation of CO2 over surfaces, promoting chemisorption. In this study, the left leg of the volcano curve was accumulated by Ru catalyst, whereas the corresponding right leg was occupied by Ni3Co, Ni, Ni3Cu, Pt, and Pd catalysts. The optimum of the volcano curve was obtained for Ni3Fe and Rh catalysts with respective dissociative adsorption energies of −0.62 and −0.54 eV, as given in Table 5. Previous studies on the particular class of hydrogenation reactions of diatomic molecules such as CO, N2, and NO revealed that the highly active catalysts with optimal dissociative adsorption energy are from −1 to −2 eV, specifically known as the “chemical window” [50,52]. In the case of CO2 hydrogenation, as mentioned previously, the Ediss of the highly active catalysts lies between 0 to −1 eV, as shown in Fig. 7(B). The shift in the “chemical window” observed in our work can be mainly due to three reasons: (i) despite falling in the same category as CO hydrogenation, CO2 hydrogenation involves a triatomic molecule CO2, (ii) in the case of diatomic molecule hydrogenation, the concept of “chemical window” is defined for pure metals, whereas in our case the most active metal is Ni3Fe bimetallic alloy, and (iii) to define a chemical window in case of hydrogenation of triatomic molecule, different types of reaction has to be performed and analyzed, which may give a broader range including 0 to −1 eV as obtained in this study. Previous studies on CO hydrogenation explained the volcano curve with the help of a Brønsted-Evans-Polanyi (BEP) plot, which correlates the activation barrier to the enthalpy of CO dissociation [50,54]. Here, the volcano curves result in an optimum with corresponding Ru, Co catalysts when both CO dissociative adsorption and CO dissociation energy were correlated with experimental activity. No positional changes of elements were observed on the left and right legs of volcano curves when plotted with the two descriptors as mentioned above, even though their absolute value differs. This is due to the interdependence between dissociative adsorption and dissociation energy, which linearly correlates with the CO dissociation barrier through a BEP plot. So, in the same way in our study, the volcano plot obtained can be explained well by connecting with the concept of BEP plot, i.e., CO2 is weakly adsorbed on Ni, Ni3Co, Ni3Cu, Pt, and Pd catalysts which lie on the right leg of the volcano, where the barrier of dissociation is high and limits the rate. On Ru catalysts, which lie on the left leg of the volcano, CO2 is strongly adsorbed, resulting in low removal rates of adsorbed CO and O from the surface, whereas on Ni3Fe and Rh catalysts, dissociative adsorption of CO2 is neither too strong nor too weak, it is just right. This represents an optimum for the enthalpy of dissociative adsorption of CO2 on the surface active sites to the intrinsic catalytic activity, making Ni3Fe and Rh catalysts potential candidates for CO2 methanation. In this CO2 methanation study, it is found that 75Ni25Fe is a low-cost catalyst relative to Rh and has higher catalytic activity than the notably active Noble metal Ru and the primary metal, i.e., Ni, belonging to the right leg on the volcano. 4 Conclusions Catalytic CO2 methanation is one of the key enabling technologies for the utilization of captured CO2 and storage of renewably produced H2. The γ-Al2O3 supported metallic Pt, Pd, Rh, and Ru termed as Noble, whereas Ni, and bimetallic Ni-M (M = Co, Cu, Fe, with Ni/M = 3:1 by weight) termed as Non-noble catalysts were synthesized, characterized and tested for CO2 methanation. By keeping a total metal loading of 3 wt% (for Noble) and 15 wt% (for Non-noble), these catalysts were synthesized by Incipient wetness impregnation method and characterized by EDS, BET, TPR, XRD, FESEM, TEM and H2-TPD techniques. The actual metal loading, as measured by EDS (bulk) was found to be close to the nominal loading for all the catalysts. It was observed that Noble metals achieved almost complete reduction and lower onset of reduction temperature in comparison to Non-noble metals. However, bulk oxide species in each of the bimetallic Ni-M catalysts were found to reduce at a lower temperature than bulk NiO, suggesting better reducibility achieved. The formation of a potential alloy phase in each Ni-M catalyst was substantiated by observed peak shift (∼ 0.2–0.4º) in XRD, whereas for Noble metals, the individual metallic phases were highly dispersed and were not detected. Interestingly, for Non-noble catalysts, FESEM and TEM analysis reveals a similar trend (Ni-Fe < Ni-Co < Ni-Cu < Ni) in their average particle size, but for Noble catalysts, a similar trend is not observed (100Rh < 100Ru < 100 Pd ∼ 100Pt) due to difference in the average particle size of 100Pt and 100 Pd. All the catalysts were active towards CO2 methanation; however, Ni-Fe and Rh showed maximum turnover frequency for CO2 conversion (∼ 3.2 × 10−2 sec−1). Furthermore, 100Ru and 100Rh had better CH4 selectivity (∼99 %) than the Ni-Fe (95 %) catalyst. On chemisorption induced surfaces, CO2 prefers to adsorbed dissociatively rather than remaining in its associative nature. The present study reveals that the optimal dissociative adsorption of CO2 ranges between 0 to −1 eV for the most active and almost competitive catalysts: Ni-Fe alloy catalyst and metallic Rh. This “chemical window”, as identified by DFT calculations and correlating with catalytic activity i.e. TOF CO 2 at 523 K, reveals a volcano trend among Noble and Non-noble catalysts primarily. Thus, a superior descriptor has been identified that can characterize the potential catalysts with their activity for CO2 methanation. Insights obtained from this study collectively for the Noble metal and Non-noble Ni-based alloy bimetallic catalysts and knowledge of the defined descriptor will further enrich the input database for machine learning based catalyst screening. coredata.dc:description: Supported Pt, Pd, Rh, Ru as Noble and Ni, bimetallic Ni-M (M = Co, Cu, Fe, with Ni/M = 3:1 by weight) as Non-noble catalysts were synthesized, characterized, and tested for CO2 methanation to benchmark and obtain a suitable descriptor. Noble metal catalysts are reduced almost completely with a lower onset of reduction temperature than Non-noble catalysts. The reduced Ni-M catalysts possessed an alloy phase in each as substantiated by a peak shift (∼ 0.2–0.4º) with reference to metallic nickel. The catalysts are benchmarked for their activity at 523 K by reporting turnover frequency ( TOF CO 2 ). The Ni-Fe and Rh catalysts possess maximum TOF CO 2 (∼ 35 × 10−3 sec−1), while Ru, Rh catalysts have better CH4 selectivity (∼99 %) than Ni-Fe (95 %) catalyst. The knowledge of descriptor is revisited for this reaction by calculating surface properties and observed that there exists a volcano relationship between dissociative CO2 adsorption energy (Ediss) and TOF CO 2 .
